text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with olive oil poached tuna that's
right this remarkably delicious
technique is also sometimes referred to
as tuna confit or if you want to sound
more like a food blogger you can also
call it tuna conserva but no matter what
you call it this is actually the ancient
ancestor of what most of us refer to
today as tuna fish and by the way I
should apologize in advance you're not
going to be able to go back to the
canned stuff so yes in the long run this
video is going to cost you a lot of
money so let me show you how to put this
together and the first thing we're going
to need is some beautiful tuna and as
you can see here I have two gorgeous
tuna steaks nice and thick
beautifully red that would be the ahi
tuna and that's usually going to come
fully trimmed no bones so there's really
no prep here but what I do want you to
do is take it out of the fridge and
leave it on the counter for 10 to 15
minutes to warm up a little bit okay
because we are going to poach this in
the olive oil we don't want it really
ice-cold when it goes in there so like I
said let it sit out for about 10 or 15
minutes and at that point we can get
started so we're gonna head over to the
stove where we're going to toss a couple
cloves of crushed garlic into a heavy
skillet a medium heat as you can see I
didn't even peel them doesn't matter and
then we're to go ahead and pour in about
an inch of olive oil now any decent
olive oil is going to work here you
don't necessarily have to use extra
virgin and I actually am using extra
virgin although I will admit is not a
super expensive one so this is not
something you really want to use your
expensive premium olive oil for but
anyway we're going to pour that oil in
I'm also going to throw in a handful of
fresh thyme leaves and I know I've said
this before but plan some time in your
backyard and if you just said I don't
have the time exactly that's my point
and not only does time taste great it's
also on your side okay so plant some of
that as soon as you can and then in
addition to the fresh herb I'm also
going to put in a good amount of red
chili flakes and I'll give that a little
stir and then basically all we're doing
is waiting for this to get hot enough to
add our tuna it's going to be very easy
to know when that happens the thyme and
the garlic are going to act as
indicators and when those starts
sizzling in the oil we know it's up to
temp and at first it's going to start
slowly you'll see just a few little
bubbles starting to pop out of that
garlic clove and then as the temperature
increases a few more bubbles and by the
way if that paper skin comes off your
crushed garlic clove and it annoys you
like this did me pull it out and
basically what we're looking for is this
the herbs and the garlic
start bubbling enthusiastically and when
you do see a bubbling like that that is
your indication to carefully go ahead
and add the tuna to the pan and then
very critical as soon as we have the
tuna to the pan we're going to turn the
heat down to low repeat turn your heat
down to low and we're going to go ahead
and we're going to let that tuna sit in
that hot flavorful oil for about five to
seven minutes while we baste it
constantly
except you know it's a terrible tool for
doing this tongs so let's lose the tongs
and switch to a spoon so I'm pretty much
going to stand there basting constantly
and of course you can see that top turn
from that deep red color to that pallor
cook tuna color and by the way this is
optional but I did have some extra time
sprigs so I went ahead and threw them on
top I'm just basting the top of plain
tuna steaks is pretty fun but when you
get to spoon it over additional fresh
thyme sprigs it gets even more exciting
and by the way traditionally tuna comfy
tuna conserva whatever you want to call
this is cooked all the way through but
as you'll see using this method you
should have a little bit of pinkness
left inside in the thicker parts one of
the great things about this technique is
that it will work for you whether you
want your tuna well-done cooked all the
way through or just barely cooked around
the outside and still pretty rare in the
middle so I am going to give a lot more
info about thymes on the blog but anyway
like I said we're going to base that for
about five to seven minutes on low at
which point we will turn off the heat
and very carefully transfer that into a
heatproof dish and then once we've done
that we're going to carefully very
carefully pour over that still fairly
hot oil and we're going to let that cool
down to room temperature in that oil if
you want to give it a baste every once
in a while go ahead up to you that's
mostly just playing around with the food
anyway we'll go ahead and let that cool
all the way down to room temperature at
which point we'll wrap it tightly with
the plastic pressed right up against the
fish and oil you know how we do and then
we'll pop that in the fridge for 24
hours to finish doing its thing which by
the way nobody knows exactly what that
is scientists have still not figured it
out but during that 24 hours something
very magical happens and when you pull
it out and you unwrap it and you fish
out one of those tuna steaks pun
intended if your future reference all
puns are intended okay we're going to
pull one of those out and that will
bring us to my favorite part explaining
to you how amazing this is
so let me start with a little corner
piece and even though the meat around
the outside is cooked all the way
through it is still unbelievably moist
and succulent
textures beautifully buttery and the
flavor amazing and by the way you may
have noticed we didn't put any salt so
far I really think this comes out better
if you don't use any salt in the
poaching process I think it's much nicer
and much easier to control if you just
sprinkle on a little sea salt when you
serve it so that was amazing but it gets
better as we slice in you're going to
see a gorgeous pink tinge I mean look at
that and that right there my friends is
olive oil poached tuna perfection if
you've ever had that really expensive
imported tuna belly it comes packed in
the oil believe it or not this is
remarkably close and generally is a
strategy I'll use the pink err stuff for
salads for appetizers maybe a tartare
like preparation and then for the more
well-done parts the parts that are
cooked all the way through that
generally gets saved for sandwiches
which reminds me until you've had a tuna
salad sandwich made with this stuff you
actually have not had a tuna salad
sandwich so you got that to look forward
to but regardless of what you do with
this I really really hope you give it a
try soon and then one last very
important thing before we sign off
please never forget you can tune a piano
but you cannot tuna fish okay so head
over to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
